reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s emphasis (in §2) on de dicto motivation as part of WAM-convergence, arguing de re preference-overlap could suffice. This is somewhat central to the structure of §2, but not to the essay’s overall conclusion, which explicitly considers non-de-dicto pathways in §4 (and is overall more optimistic about trade/compromise in §3). The critique’s refutation power is limited: it mainly asserts a possibility (stable overlapping instrumental subgoals) without engaging the essay’s core reasons for pessimism (narrow-target/fork arguments, increasing optimization revealing deep value divergence, and why instrumental overlap may break once ‘low-hanging fruit’ is exhausted). It also overstates by implying the paper assumes de dicto is necessary; the paper explicitly entertains cases where no one aims at the good de dicto and argues they’re unlikely under “no easy eutopia.” Still, the core point—that de dicto motivation is not strictly necessary for good outcomes in principle—is correct. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: De re convergence on instrumental goals could simulate moral alignment without de dicto motivation
